content.raw:
@{5be108d7216ccf49622e6b67}, The [cloudsim documentation on the wiki](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/qual_cloudsim) is up to date. A docker image is required, not a docker-compose.yml file. The docker-compose.yml file is used locally to mimic the [cloudsim architecture](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim_architecture). I added a couple lines about the alpha-numeric requirement for robot names.

If you need to pass arguments into your solution image, then you will have to build a separate image for each robot and incorporate the parameters into the image. This is something we'd like to change, but it's a non-trivial enhancement.

In terms of a checklist, there is nothing mandatory that you must do. You can call `/subt/start` and `/subt/finish` if you want to, but these are both optional.

Cloudsim uses the same docker versions as found on [dockerhub](https://cloud.docker.com/u/osrf/repository/docker/osrf/subt-virtual-testbed).

Checkout the [system requirements](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/system_requirements) page for information about nvidia version.
content.html:
@Sarah Kitchen, The cloudsim documentation on the wiki is up to date. A docker image is required, not a docker-compose.yml file. The docker-compose.yml file is used locally to mimic the cloudsim architecture. I added a couple lines about the alpha-numeric requirement for robot names.

If you need to pass arguments into your solution image, then you will have to build a separate image for each robot and incorporate the parameters into the image. This is something we'd like to change, but it's a non-trivial enhancement.

In terms of a checklist, there is nothing mandatory that you must do. You can call /subt/start and /subt/finish if you want to, but these are both optional.

Cloudsim uses the same docker versions as found on dockerhub.

Checkout the system requirements page for information about nvidia version.
